TableÂ 1, we provide a detailed list of the input/output format for instruction fine-turning.
To generalize instruction tuning, we collect publicly available multilingual translation prompts fromÂ Bawden and Yvon (2023) and PromptSourceÂ Bach etÂ al. (2022) in TableÂ 1, and randomly select prompt and parallel sentence to combine as model input. Accordingly, the instruction tuning dataset is scrambled to ensure diversity and randomness. When doing the inference, we also randomly select the aforementioned translation prompts, in TableÂ 1, to generalize the evaluation results.

references:
Our training data always has either the source or the target in EnglishÂ Schioppa etÂ al. (2023). We select 8 language pairs in OPUS-100222https://object.pouta.csc.fi/OPUS-100/v1.0/opus-100-corpus-v1.0.tar.gz for training and evaluating. To guarantee the quality of the training data, we use the LABSE Feng etÂ al. (2020) tool to select sentences with similarity scores above 0.75.
Since our goal is to explore the translation ability of LLM and reduce the impact of parallel corpus on LLM, we limit the number of parallel sentences for training and validation to 2,000 per language pair, which follows the same settings asÂ Li etÂ al. (2023).
In order to minimize the possibility of overlap with mT0â€™s training corpus and enable comparisons with state-of-the-art (SOTA) systems, we use the WMT 14, 16 and 22 benchmarks for evaluation. We evaluate our model and baselines on news data from the WMT 2022Â Vilar etÂ al. (2022); Kocmi etÂ al. (2022) evaluation campaign. WMT 22 moves away from testing only on the news domain like in previous years and shifts to focus on the general scenario covering news, social, conversational, and e-commerce.
Since Hindi, French and Romanian are common evaluated and not included in WMT 22, we use test data from WMT 14 and WMT 16.
TableÂ 2 and TableÂ 3 show statistics for our training, validation, and test data (since each language pair contains two directions, we multiply each cell by 2).

references:
The average results on both zero-shot and supervised directions, along with other baselines, are shown in Table 4, where the best result is displayed in bold.
According to Table 4, we can find that both TECT-MNMT and ACT-MNMT outperform all baselines in terms of all evaluation metrics at all levels (except the perplexity), based on the average results for all translation directions, and even outperforms larger models, such as mT0-xxl 13B.
Specifically, TECT-MNMT improves 0.44, and ACT-MNMT improves 0.37 in scareBLEU compared to the bested performed baseline, mFTI.
Furthermore, ACT-MNMT achieves the minimum OT ratio, SC ratio and OUG ratio, as well as the maximum chrF-style score.
These results indicate that the auto-constriction template can assist LLM in better understanding instructions and minimize translation issues (e.g.Â , misunderstanding of instructions issue, off-target translation issue, source copy issue and over/under generation issue).
The main reason is that our designed constrained template on the target side can extract trigger tokens as additional supervised information.

references:
We show the result in Table 7.
We observe that as the number of common trigger tokens and specific trigger tokens increases, the performance of the model gradually decreases.
In addition, when analyzing the experimental results in depth, we observe that perplexity is highly sensitive in the translation direction from Chinese to English.
Specifically, when the number of common trigger token and specific trigger token change from 1 to 3, the perplexity in the Chinese to English direction changes from 234.89 changes 180.75.
This greatly reduces the average improvement in other translation directions.
